member.summary: Represents the <messaging> element in the host's .config file.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.UntrustedWebRequestElementName
member.summary: The name of the <untrustedWebRequest> sub-element.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumMessageLifetimeConfigName
member.summary: The name of the attribute that stores the association's maximum lifetime.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumClockSkewConfigName
member.summary: The name of the attribute that stores the maximum allowable clock skew.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.StrictConfigName
member.summary: The name of the attribute that controls whether messaging rules are strictly followed.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.DefaultMaximumIndirectMessageUrlLength
member.summary: The default value for the property.
member.value: 2KB, recommended by OpenID group

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumIndirectMessageUrlLengthConfigName
member.summary: The name of the attribute that controls the maximum length of a URL before it is converted to a POST payload.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumMessageLifetime
member.summary: Gets the actual maximum message lifetime that a program should allow.
member.value: The sum of the and property values.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumMessageLifetimeNoSkew
member.summary: Gets or sets the time between a message's creation and its receipt before it is considered expired.
member.value: The default value value is 3 minutes.

remarks.para: Smaller timespans mean lower tolerance for delays in message delivery. Larger timespans mean more nonces must be stored to provide replay protection.
The maximum age a message implementing the interface can be before being discarded as too old.
This time limit should NOT take into account expected time skew for servers across the Internet. Time skew is added to this value and is controlled by the property.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumClockSkew
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum clock skew.
member.value: The default value is 10 minutes.

remarks.para: Smaller timespans mean lower tolerance for time variance due to server clocks not being synchronized. Larger timespans mean greater chance for replay attacks and larger nonce caches.
For example, if a server could conceivably have its clock d = 5 minutes off UTC time, then any two servers could have their clocks disagree by as much as 2*d = 10 minutes.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.Strict
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether messaging rules are strictly adhered to.
member.value: true by default.
member.remarks: Strict will require that remote parties adhere strictly to the specifications, even when a loose interpretation would not compromise security. true is a good default because it shakes out interoperability bugs in remote services so they can be identified and corrected. But some web sites want things to Just Work more than they want to file bugs against others, so false is the setting for them.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.UntrustedWebRequest
member.summary: Gets or sets the configuration for the class.
member.value: The untrusted web request.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.MessagingElement.MaximumIndirectMessageUrlLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum allowable size for a 301 Redirect response before we send a 200 OK response with a scripted form POST with the parameters instead in order to ensure successfully sending a large payload to another server that might have a maximum allowable size restriction on its GET request.
member.value: The default value is 2048.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OAuthServiceProviderSecuritySettingsElement.MinimumRequiredOAuthVersion
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum OAuth version a Consumer is required to support in order for this library to interoperate with it.
member.remarks: Although the earliest versions of OAuth are supported, for security reasons it may be desirable to require the remote party to support a later version of OAuth.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OAuthServiceProviderSecuritySettingsElement.MaximumRequestTokenTimeToLive
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum time a user can take to complete authorization.
member.remarks: This time limit serves as a security mitigation against brute force attacks to compromise (unauthorized or authorized) request tokens. Longer time limits is more friendly to slow users or consumers, while shorter time limits provide better security.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.RequireSsl
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether all discovery and authentication should require SSL security.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.RequireDirectedIdentity
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether only OP Identifiers will be discoverable when creating authentication requests.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.RequireAssociation
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether authentication requests will only be created where an association with the Provider can be established.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.MinimumRequiredOpenIdVersion
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum OpenID version a Provider is required to support in order for this library to interoperate with it.
member.remarks: Although the earliest versions of OpenID are supported, for security reasons it may be desirable to require the remote party to support a later version of OpenID.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.MinimumHashBitLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum length of the hash that protects the protocol from hijackers.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.MaximumHashBitLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum length of the hash that protects the protocol from hijackers.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.PrivateSecretMaximumAge
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum allowable age of the secret a Relying Party uses to its return_to URLs and nonces with 1.0 Providers.
member.value: The default value is 7 days.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.RejectUnsolicitedAssertions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether all unsolicited assertions should be ignored.
member.value: The default value is false.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.RejectDelegatingIdentifiers
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether delegating identifiers are refused for authentication.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: When set to true, login attempts that start at the RP or arrive via unsolicited assertions will be rejected if discovery on the identifier shows that OpenID delegation is used for the identifier. This is useful for an RP that should only accept identifiers directly issued by the Provider that is sending the assertion.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.IgnoreUnsignedExtensions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether unsigned extensions in authentication responses should be ignored.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: When set to true, the methods will not return any extension that was not signed by the Provider.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.AllowDualPurposeIdentifiers
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether identifiers that are both OP Identifiers and Claimed Identifiers should ever be recognized as claimed identifiers.
member.value: The default value is false, per the OpenID 2.0 spec.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.AllowApproximateIdentifierDiscovery
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether certain Claimed Identifiers that exploit features that .NET does not have the ability to send exact HTTP requests for will still be allowed by using an approximate HTTP request.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.ProtectDownlevelReplayAttacks
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Relying Party should take special care to protect users against replay attacks when interoperating with OpenID 1.1 Providers.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.OpenIdRelyingPartySecuritySettingsElement.TrustedProviders
member.summary: Gets or sets the set of trusted OpenID Provider Endpoints.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Configuration.TypeConfigurationElement`1.CreateInstanceFromXaml(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Creates the instance from xaml.
member.param: The stream of xaml to deserialize.
member.returns: The deserialized object.
member.remarks: This exists as its own method to prevent the CLR's JIT compiler from failing to compile the CreateInstance method just because the PresentationFramework.dll may be missing (which it is on some shared web hosts). member.summary: Extension methods for types.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.EnumerableCacheExtensions.CacheGeneratedResults``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Caches the results of enumerating over a given object so that subsequence enumerations don't require interacting with the object a second time.
member.typeparam: The type of element found in the enumeration.
member.param: The enumerable object.
member.returns: Either a new enumerable object that caches enumerated results, or the original, object if no caching is necessary to avoid additional CPU work.

remarks.para: This is designed for use on the results of generator methods (the ones with yield return in them) so that only those elements in the sequence that are needed are ever generated, while not requiring regeneration of elements that are enumerated over multiple times.
This can be a huge performance gain if enumerating multiple times over an expensive generator method.

Some enumerable types such as collections, lists, and already-cached generators do not require any (additional) caching, and this method will simply return those objects rather than caching them to avoid double-caching.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.EnumerableCacheExtensions.EnumerableCache`1
member.summary: A wrapper for types and returns a caching from its method.
member.typeparam: The type of element in the sequence.

member.summary: The results from enumeration of the live object that have been collected thus far.

member.summary: The original generator method or other enumerable object whose contents should only be enumerated once.

member.summary: The enumerator we're using over the generator method's results.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.EnumerableCacheExtensions.EnumerableCache`1.generatorLock
member.summary: The sync object our caching enumerators use when adding a new live generator method result to the cache.
member.remarks: Although individual enumerators are not thread-safe, this should be thread safe so that multiple enumerators can be created from it and used from different threads.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ICombinedOpenIdProviderTokenManager
member.summary: An interface that providers that play a dual role as OpenID Provider and OAuth Service Provider should implement on their token manager classes.
member.remarks: This interface should be implemented by the same class that implements in order to enable the OpenID+OAuth extension.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IOpenIdOAuthTokenManager
member.summary: Additional methods an implementing class may implement to support the OpenID+OAuth extension.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IOpenIdOAuthTokenManager.StoreOpenIdAuthorizedRequestToken(System.String,DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.OAuth.AuthorizationApprovedResponse)
member.summary: Stores a new request token obtained over an OpenID request.
member.param: The consumer key.
The authorization message carrying the request token and authorized access scope.

remarks.para: The token secret is the empty string.

Tokens stored by this method should be short-lived to mitigate possible security threats. Their lifetime should be sufficient for the relying party to receive the positive authentication assertion and immediately send a follow-up request for the access token.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ITokenManager
member.summary: An interface OAuth hosts must implement for persistent storage and recall of tokens and secrets for an individual OAuth consumer or service provider.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ITokenManager.GetTokenSecret(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the Token Secret given a request or access token.
member.param: The request or access token.
member.returns: The secret associated with the given token.
member.exception: Thrown if the secret cannot be found for the given token.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ITokenManager.StoreNewRequestToken(DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.Messages.UnauthorizedTokenRequest,DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.Messages.ITokenSecretContainingMessage)
member.summary: Stores a newly generated unauthorized request token, secret, and optional application-specific parameters for later recall.
member.param: The request message that resulted in the generation of a new unauthorized request token.
The response message that includes the unauthorized request token.
member.exception: Thrown if the consumer key is not registered, or a required parameter was not found in the parameters collection.
member.remarks: Request tokens stored by this method SHOULD NOT associate any user account with this token. It usually opens up security holes in your application to do so. Instead, you associate a user account with access tokens (not request tokens) in the method.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ITokenManager.ExpireRequestTokenAndStoreNewAccessToken(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Deletes a request token and its associated secret and stores a new access token and secret.
member.param: The Consumer that is exchanging its request token for an access token.
The Consumer's request token that should be deleted/expired.
The new access token that is being issued to the Consumer.
The secret associated with the newly issued access token.

remarks.para: Any scope of granted privileges associated with the request token from the original call to should be carried over to the new Access Token.

To associate a user account with the new access token, HttpContext.Current.User may be useful in an ASP.NET web application within the implementation of this method. Alternatively you may store the access token here without associating with a user account, and wait until or return the access token to associate the access token with a user account at that point.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ITokenManager.GetTokenType(System.String)
member.summary: Classifies a token as a request token or an access token.
member.param: The token to classify.
member.returns: Request or Access token, or invalid if the token is not recognized.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.ICombinedOpenIdProviderTokenManager.GetConsumerKey(DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Realm)
member.summary: Gets the OAuth consumer key for a given OpenID relying party realm.
member.param: The relying party's OpenID realm.
member.returns: The OAuth consumer key for a given OpenID realm.
member.para: This is a security-critical function. Since OpenID requests and OAuth extensions for those requests can be formulated by ANYONE (no signing is required by the relying party), and since the response to the authentication will include access the user is granted to the relying party who CLAIMS to be from some realm, it is of paramount importance that the realm is recognized as belonging to the consumer key by the host service provider in order to protect against phishers.

member.summary: A description of a consumer from a Service Provider's point of view.

member.value: A set of characters that can be easily keyed in by the user given the Consumer's application type and form factor.
member.remarks: The value should NEVER be returned since this property is only used in no callback scenarios anyway.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IConsumerDescription.VerificationCodeLength
member.summary: Gets the length of the verification code to issue for this Consumer.
member.value: A positive number, generally at least 4.

member.summary: Checks whether a given request token has already been authorized by some user for use by the Consumer that requested it.
member.param: The Consumer's request token.
member.returns: True if the request token has already been fully authorized by the user who owns the relevant protected resources. False if the token has not yet been authorized, has expired or does not exist.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IServiceProviderTokenManager.GetRequestToken(System.String)
member.summary: Gets details on the named request token.
member.param: The request token.
member.returns: A description of the token. Never null.
member.exception: Thrown if the token cannot be found.
member.remarks: It is acceptable for implementations to find the token, see that it has expired, delete it from the database and then throw , or alternatively it can return the expired token anyway and the OAuth channel will log and throw the appropriate error.

member.exception: Thrown if the token cannot be found.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IServiceProviderTokenManager.UpdateToken(DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.IServiceProviderRequestToken)
member.summary: Persists any changes made to the token.
member.param: The token whose properties have been changed.
member.remarks: This library will invoke this method after making a set of changes to the token as part of a web request to give the host the opportunity to persist those changes to a database. Depending on the object persistence framework the host site uses, this method MAY not need to do anything (if changes made to the token will automatically be saved without any extra handling).

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.DesktopConsumer
member.summary: Used by a desktop application to use OAuth to access the Service Provider on behalf of the User.
member.remarks: The methods on this class are thread-safe. Provided the properties are set and not changed afterward, a single instance of this class may be used by an entire desktop application safely.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

The host's method of storing and recalling tokens and secrets.

member.summary: Begins an OAuth authorization request.
member.param: Extra parameters to add to the request token message. Optional.
Extra parameters to add to the redirect to Service Provider message. Optional.
The request token that must be exchanged for an access token after the user has provided authorization.
member.returns: The URL to open a browser window to allow the user to provide authorization.

member.summary: Exchanges a given request token for access token.
member.param: The request token that the user has authorized.

member.summary: Exchanges a given request token for access token.
member.param: The request token that the user has authorized.
The verifier code typed in by the user. Must not be Null for OAuth 1.0a service providers and later.
member.returns: The access token assigned by the Service Provider.

member.summary: Prevents a default instance of the class from being created.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.IMessageWithBinaryDataContract.DotNetOpenAuth#Messaging#IMessage#EnsureValidMessage
member.summary: Checks the message state for conformity to the protocol specification and throws an exception if the message is invalid.

remarks.para: Some messages have required fields, or combinations of fields that must relate to each other in specialized ways. After deserializing a message, this method checks the state of the message to see if it conforms to the protocol.
Note that this property should not check signatures or perform any state checks outside this scope of this particular message.

member.exception: Thrown if the message is invalid.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.IMessageWithBinaryDataContract.DotNetOpenAuth#Messaging#IMessageWithBinaryData#BinaryData
member.summary: Gets the parts of the message that carry binary data.

member.summary: Prepares a message for sending based on the rules of this channel binding element.
member.param: The message to prepare for sending.
member.returns: The protections (if any) that this binding element applied to the message. Null if this binding element did not even apply to this binding element.

member.summary: Performs any transformation on an incoming message that may be necessary and/or validates an incoming message based on the rules of this channel binding element.

member.returns: The protections (if any) that this binding element applied to the message. Null if this binding element did not even apply to this binding element.
member.exception: Thrown when the binding element rules indicate that this message is invalid and should NOT be processed.
member.remarks: Implementations that provide message protection must honor the properties where applicable.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.Bindings.IReplayProtectedProtocolMessage
member.summary: The contract a message that has an allowable time window for processing must implement.
member.remarks: All replay-protected messages must also be set to expire so the nonces do not have to be stored indefinitely.

member.summary: Gets the context within which the nonce must be unique.

member.summary: Gets or sets the nonce that will protect the message from replay attacks.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.Bindings.INonceStore.StoreNonce(System.String,System.String,System.DateTime)
member.summary: Stores a given nonce and timestamp.
member.param: The context, or namespace, within which the must be unique. The context SHOULD be treated as case-sensitive. The value will never be null but may be the empty string.
A series of random characters.
The UTC timestamp that together with the nonce string make it unique within the given . The timestamp may also be used by the data store to clear out old nonces.
member.returns: True if the context+nonce+timestamp (combination) was not previously in the database. False if the nonce was stored previously with the same timestamp and context.
member.remarks:
The nonce must be stored for no less than the maximum time window a message may be processed within before being discarded as an expired message. This maximum message age can be looked up via the
property, accessible via the property.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ServiceProviderSecuritySettings
member.summary: Security settings that are applicable to service providers.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ServiceProviderSecuritySettings.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ServiceProviderSecuritySettings.MinimumRequiredOAuthVersion
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum required version of OAuth that must be implemented by a Consumer.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ServiceProviderSecuritySettings.MaximumRequestTokenTimeToLive
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum time a user can take to complete authorization.
member.remarks: This time limit serves as a security mitigation against brute force attacks to compromise (unauthorized or authorized) request tokens. Longer time limits is more friendly to slow users or consumers, while shorter time limits provide better security.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat
member.summary: The different formats a user authorization verifier code can take in order to be as secure as possible while being compatible with the type of OAuth Consumer requesting access.
member.remarks: Some Consumers may be set-top boxes, video games, mobile devies, etc. with very limited character entry support and no ability to receive a callback URI. OAuth 1.0a requires that these devices operators must manually key in a verifier code, so in these cases it better be possible to do so given the input options on that device.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat.IncludedInCallback
member.summary: The strongest verification code. The best option for web consumers since a callback is usually an option.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat.AlphaNumericNoLookAlikes
member.summary: A combination of upper and lowercase letters and numbers may be used, allowing a computer operator to easily read from the screen and key in the verification code.
member.remarks: Some letters and numbers will be skipped where they are visually similar enough that they can be difficult to distinguish when displayed with most fonts.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat.AlphaUpper
member.summary: Only uppercase letters will be used in the verification code. Verification codes are case-sensitive, so consumers with fixed keyboards with only one character case option may require this option.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat.AlphaLower
member.summary: Only lowercase letters will be used in the verification code. Verification codes are case-sensitive, so consumers with fixed keyboards with only one character case option may require this option.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.VerificationCodeFormat.Numeric
member.summary: Only the numbers 0-9 will be used in the verification code. Must useful for consumers running on mobile phone devices.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections
member.summary: Categorizes the various types of channel binding elements so they can be properly ordered.
member.remarks: The order of these enum values is significant. Each successive value requires the protection offered by all the previous values in order to be reliable. For example, message expiration is meaningless without tamper protection to prevent a user from changing the timestamp on a message.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections.None
member.summary: No protection.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections.TamperProtection
member.summary: A binding element that signs a message before sending and validates its signature upon receiving.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections.Expiration
member.summary: A binding element that enforces a maximum message age between sending and processing on the receiving side.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections.ReplayProtection
member.summary: A binding element that prepares messages for replay detection and detects replayed messages on the receiving side.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageProtections.All
member.summary: All forms of protection together.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.Messages.UserAuthorizationResponse.VerificationCode
member.summary: Gets or sets the verification code that must accompany the request to exchange the authorized request token for an access token.
member.value: An unguessable value passed to the Consumer via the User and REQUIRED to complete the process.
member.remarks: If the Consumer did not provide a callback URL, the Service Provider SHOULD display the value of the verification code, and instruct the User to manually inform the Consumer that authorization is completed. If the Service Provider knows a Consumer to be running on a mobile device or set-top box, the Service Provider SHOULD ensure that the verifier value is suitable for manual entry.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessagingUtilities.EqualsConstantTime(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Compares to string values for ordinal equality in such a way that its execution time does not depend on how much of the value matches.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
member.returns: A value indicating whether the two strings share ordinal equality.
member.remarks: In signature equality checks, a difference in execution time based on how many initial characters match MAY be used as an attack to figure out the expected signature. It is therefore important to make a signature equality check's execution time independent of how many characters match the expected value. See http://codahale.com/a-lesson-in-timing-attacks/ for more information.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.OutgoingWebResponse
member.summary: A protocol message (request or response) that passes from this to a remote party via the user agent using a redirect or form POST submission, OR a direct message response.

remarks.para: An instance of this type describes the HTTP response that must be sent in response to the current HTTP request.

It is important that this response make up the entire HTTP response. A hosting ASPX page should not be allowed to render its normal HTML output after this response is sent. The normal rendered output of an ASPX page can be canceled by calling after this message is sent on the response stream.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.Loggers.ILog
member.summary: The ILog interface is use by application to log messages into the log4net framework.

remarks.para: Use the to obtain logger instances that implement this interface. The static method is used to get logger instances.
This class contains methods for logging at different levels and also has properties for determining if those logging levels are enabled in the current configuration.

This interface can be implemented in different ways. This documentation specifies reasonable behavior that a caller can expect from the actual implementation, however different implementations reserve the right to do things differently.

member.author: Nicko Cadell
Gert Driesen

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Loggers.ILog.Debug(System.Object)
member.overloads: Log a message object with the level.
member.summary: Log a message object with the level.
member.param: The message object to log.

remarks.para: This method first checks if this logger is DEBUG enabled by comparing the level of this logger with the level. If this logger is DEBUG enabled, then it converts the message object (passed as parameter) to a string by invoking the appropriate . It then proceeds to call all the registered appenders in this logger and also higher in the hierarchy depending on the value of the additivity flag.
WARNING Note that passing an to this method will print the name of the but no stack trace. To print a stack trace use the form instead.

member.summary: Log a message object with the level including the stack trace of the passed as a parameter.
member.param: The message object to log.
The exception to log, including its stack trace.

remarks.para: See the form for more detailed information.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.Loggers.ILog.DebugFormat(System.String,System.Object[])
member.overloads: Log a formatted string with the level.
member.summary: Logs a formatted message string with the level.
member.param: A String containing zero or more format items
An Object array containing zero or more objects to format

remarks.para: The message is formatted using the String.Format method. See for details of the syntax of the format string and the behavior of the formatting.
This method does not take an object to include in the log event. To pass an use one of the methods instead.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.Loggers.ILog.IsDebugEnabled
member.summary: Checks if this logger is enabled for the level.
member.value: true if this logger is enabled for events, false otherwise.

remarks.para: This function is intended to lessen the computational cost of disabled log debug statements.
For some ILog interface log, when you write:
You incur the cost constructing the message, string construction and concatenation in this case, regardless of whether the message is logged or not.
If you are worried about speed (who isn't), then you should write:

This way you will not incur the cost of parameter construction if debugging is disabled for log. On the other hand, if the log is debug enabled, you will incur the cost of evaluating whether the logger is debug enabled twice. Once in and once in the . This is an insignificant overhead since evaluating a logger takes about 1% of the time it takes to actually log. This is the preferred style of logging.
Alternatively if your logger is available statically then the is debug enabled state can be stored in a static variable like this:
remarks.code: private static readonly bool isDebugEnabled = log.IsDebugEnabled;
remarks.para: Then when you come to log you can write:

This way the debug enabled state is only queried once when the class is loaded. Using a private static readonly variable is the most efficient because it is a run time constant and can be heavily optimized by the JIT compiler.

Of course if you use a static readonly variable to hold the enabled state of the logger then you cannot change the enabled state at runtime to vary the logging that is produced. You have to decide if you need absolute speed or runtime flexibility.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OAuth.ChannelElements.OAuthServiceProviderMessageFactory.GetNewRequestMessage(DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.MessageReceivingEndpoint,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.String})
member.summary: Analyzes an incoming request message payload to discover what kind of message is embedded in it and returns the type, or null if no match is found.

The name/value pairs that make up the message payload.

member.summary: Analyzes an incoming request message payload to discover what kind of message is embedded in it and returns the type, or null if no match is found.
member.param: The message that was sent as a request that resulted in the response. Null on a Consumer site that is receiving an indirect message from the Service Provider.
The name/value pairs that make up the message payload.
member.returns: The -derived concrete class that this message can deserialize to. Null if the request isn't recognized as a valid protocol message.
member.remarks: The response messages are: None.

The byte array returned by a call to on the previous instance.
member.returns: The newly dehydrated , which can be returned from a custom association store's method.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.SerializePrivateData
member.summary: Returns private data required to persist this in permanent storage (a shared database for example) for deserialization later.
member.returns: An opaque byte array that must be stored and returned exactly as it is provided here. The byte array may vary in length depending on the specific type of , but in current versions are no larger than 256 bytes.
member.remarks: Values of public properties on the base class are not included in this byte array, as they are useful for fast database lookup and are persisted separately.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.SecretKey
member.summary: Gets the shared secret key between the consumer and provider.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.DumbSecretLifetime
member.summary: Gets the duration a secret key used for signing dumb client requests will be good for.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.TotalLifeLength
member.summary: Gets the lifetime the OpenID provider permits this .

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.MinimumUsefulAssociationLifetime
member.summary: Gets the minimum lifetime an association must still be good for in order for it to be used for a future authentication.
member.remarks: Associations that are not likely to last the duration of a user login are not worth using at all.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association.TimeTillExpiration
member.summary: Gets the TimeSpan till this association expires.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.AssociationMemoryStore`1
member.summary: Manages a set of associations in memory only (no database).
member.typeparam: The type of the key.
member.remarks: This class should be used for low-to-medium traffic relying party sites that can afford to lose associations if the app pool was ever restarted. High traffic relying parties and providers should write their own implementation of that works against their own database schema to allow for persistance and recall of associations across servers in a web farm and server restarts.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.IAssociationStore`1
member.summary: Stores s for lookup by their handle, keeping associations separated by a given distinguishing factor (like which server the association is with).
member.typeparam: for consumers (to distinguish associations across servers) or for providers (to distinguish dumb and smart client associations).
member.remarks: Expired associations should be periodically cleared out of an association store. This should be done frequently enough to avoid a memory leak, but sparingly enough to not be a performance drain. Because this balance can vary by host, it is the responsibility of the host to initiate this cleaning.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.IAssociationStore`1.StoreAssociation(`0,DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Association)
member.summary: Saves an for later recall.
member.param: The Uri (for relying parties) or Smart/Dumb (for providers).
The association to store.
member.remarks: TODO: what should implementations do on association handle conflict?

The security requirements that the returned association must meet.

This list MUST contain at least "op_endpoint", "return_to" "response_nonce" and "assoc_handle", and if present in the response, "claimed_id" and "identity". Additional keys MAY be signed as part of the message. See Generating Signatures.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToNonceBindingElement
member.summary: This binding element adds a nonce to a Relying Party's outgoing authentication request when working against an OpenID 1.0 Provider in order to protect against replay attacks or on all authentication requests to distinguish solicited from unsolicited assertions.

remarks.para: This nonce goes beyond the OpenID 1.x spec, but adds to security. Since this library's Provider implementation also provides special nonce protection for 1.0 messages, this security feature overlaps with that one. This means that if an RP from this library were talking to an OP from this library, but the Identifier being authenticated advertised the OP as a 1.x OP, then both RP and OP might try to use a nonce for protecting the assertion. There's no problem with that--it will still all work out. And it would be a very rare combination of elements anyway.

This binding element deactivates itself for OpenID 2.0 (or later) messages since they are automatically protected in the protocol by the Provider's openid.response_nonce parameter. The exception to this is when is set to true, which will not only add a request nonce to every outgoing authentication request but also require that it be present in positive assertions, effectively disabling unsolicited assertions.

In the messaging stack, this binding element looks like an ordinary transform-type of binding element rather than a protection element, due to its required order in the channel stack and that it exists only on the RP side and only on some messages.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToNonceBindingElement.NonceParameter
member.summary: The parameter of the callback parameter we tack onto the return_to URL to store the replay-detection nonce.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToNonceBindingElement.NonceByteLength
member.summary: The length of the generated nonce's random part.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.KeyValueFormConformanceLevel.OpenId20
member.summary: The strictest mode. The decoder requires the encoded dictionary to be in strict compliance with OpenID 2.0's description of the encoding.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.OpenIdChannel.KeyValueFormContentType
member.summary: The HTTP Content-Type to use in Key-Value Form responses.
member.remarks: OpenID 2.0 section 5.1.2 says this SHOULD be text/plain. But this value does not prevent free hosters like GoDaddy from tacking on their ads to the end of the direct response, corrupting the data. So we deviate from the spec a bit here to improve the story for free Providers.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.OpenIdChannel.CreateNonVerifyingChannel
member.summary: A value indicating whether the channel is set up with no functional security binding elements.
member.returns: A new instance that will not perform verification on incoming messages or apply any security to outgoing messages.

remarks.para: A value of true allows the relying party to preview incoming messages without invalidating nonces or checking signatures.
Setting this to true poses a great security risk and is only present to support the which needs to preview messages, and will validate them later.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToSignatureBindingElement
member.summary: This binding element signs a Relying Party's openid.return_to parameter so that upon return, it can verify that it hasn't been tampered with.

remarks.para: Since Providers can send unsolicited assertions, not all openid.return_to values will be signed. But those that are signed will be validated, and any invalid or missing signatures will cause this library to not trust the parameters in the return_to URL.

In the messaging stack, this binding element looks like an ordinary transform-type of binding element rather than a protection element, due to its required order in the channel stack and that it doesn't sign anything except a particular message part.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToSignatureBindingElement.ReturnToSignatureParameterName
member.summary: The name of the callback parameter we'll tack onto the return_to value to store our signature on the return_to parameter.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToSignatureBindingElement.ReturnToSignatureHandleParameterName
member.summary: The name of the callback parameter we'll tack onto the return_to value to store the handle of the association we use to sign the return_to parameter.

member.summary: The hashing algorithm used to generate the private signature on the return_to parameter.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.ChannelElements.ReturnToSignatureBindingElement.GetReturnToSignature(System.Uri)
member.summary: Gets the return to signature.
member.param: The return to.
member.returns: The generated signature.
member.remarks: Only the parameters in the return_to URI are signed, rather than the base URI itself, in order that OPs that might change the return_to's implicit port :80 part or other minor changes do not invalidate the signature.

member.summary: Gets the protection offered (if any) by this binding element.
member.remarks: No message protection is reported because this binding element does not protect the entire message -- only a part.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.IOpenIdMessageExtension
member.summary: The contract any OpenID extension for DotNetOpenAuth must implement.
member.remarks: Classes that implement this interface should be marked as [] to allow serializing state servers to cache messages, particularly responses.

member.summary: Gets the TypeURI the extension uses in the OpenID protocol and in XRDS advertisements.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.IOpenIdMessageExtension.AdditionalSupportedTypeUris
member.summary: Gets the additional TypeURIs that are supported by this extension, in preferred order. May be empty if none other than is supported, but should not be null.
member.remarks: Useful for reading in messages with an older version of an extension. The value in the property is always checked before trying this list. If you do support multiple versions of an extension using this method, consider adding a CreateResponse method to your request extension class so that the response can have the context it needs to remain compatible given the version of the extension in the request message. The for an example.

member.value: true if this instance is signed by the sender; otherwise, false.

member.remarks: If you don't see what you need here, check that URL to see if any have been added. You can use new ones directly without adding them to this class, and can even make up your own if you expect the other end to understand what you make up.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.IClientScriptExtensionResponse
member.summary: An interface that OpenID extensions can implement to allow authentication response messages with included extensions to be processed by Javascript on the user agent.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.IClientScriptExtensionResponse.InitializeJavaScriptData(DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.IProtocolMessageWithExtensions)
member.summary: Reads the extension information on an authentication response from the provider.
member.param: The incoming OpenID response carrying the extension.
member.returns: A Javascript snippet that when executed on the user agent returns an object with the information deserialized from the extension response.
member.remarks: This method is called before the signature on the assertion response has been verified. Therefore all information in these fields should be assumed unreliable and potentially falsified.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.OAuth.AuthorizationRequest
member.summary: An extension to include with an authentication request in order to also obtain authorization to access user data at the combined OpenID Provider and Service Provider.

remarks.para: When requesting OpenID Authentication via the protocol mode "checkid_setup" or "checkid_immediate", this extension can be used to request that the end user authorize an OAuth access token at the same time as an OpenID authentication. This is done by sending the following parameters as part of the OpenID request. (Note that the use of "oauth" as part of the parameter names here and in subsequent sections is just an example. See Section 5 for details.)
See section 8.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.OAuth.AuthorizationRequest.Factory
member.summary: The factory method that may be used in deserialization of this message.

member.summary: Gets or sets a string that encodes, in a way possibly specific to the Combined Provider, one or more scopes for the OAuth token expected in the authentication response.

member.summary: The OAuth response that a Provider may include with a positive OpenID identity assertion with an approved request token.

member.summary: The factory method that may be used in deserialization of this message.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.OAuth.AuthorizationApprovedResponse.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that encodes, in a way possibly specific to the Combined Provider, one or more scopes that the returned request token is valid for. This will typically indicate a subset of the scopes requested in Section 8.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies
member.summary: Well-known authentication policies defined in the PAPE extension spec or by a recognized standards body.
member.remarks: This is a class of constants rather than a flags enum because policies may be freely defined and used by anyone, just by using a new Uri.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.PhishingResistant
member.summary: An authentication mechanism where the End User does not provide a shared secret to a party potentially under the control of the Relying Party. (Note that the potentially malicious Relying Party controls where the User-Agent is redirected to and thus may not send it to the End User's actual OpenID Provider).

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.MultiFactor
member.summary: An authentication mechanism where the End User authenticates to the OpenID Provider by providing over one authentication factor. Common authentication factors are something you know, something you have, and something you are. An example would be authentication using a password and a software token or digital certificate.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.PhysicalMultiFactor
member.summary: An authentication mechanism where the End User authenticates to the OpenID Provider by providing over one authentication factor where at least one of the factors is a physical factor such as a hardware device or biometric. Common authentication factors are something you know, something you have, and something you are. This policy also implies the Multi-Factor Authentication policy (http://schemas.openid.net/pape/policies/2007/06/multi-factor) and both policies MAY BE specified in conjunction without conflict. An example would be authentication using a password and a hardware token.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.PrivatePersonalIdentifier
member.summary: Indicates that the Provider MUST use a pair-wise pseudonym for the user that is persistent and unique across the requesting realm as the openid.claimed_id and openid.identity (see Section 4.2).

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.USGovernmentTrustLevel1
member.summary: Indicates that the OP MUST only respond with a positive assertion if the requirements demonstrated by the OP to obtain certification by a Federally adopted Trust Framework Provider have been met.
member.remarks: Notwithstanding the RP may request this authentication policy, the RP MUST still verify that this policy appears in the positive assertion response rather than assume the OP recognized and complied with the request.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.NoPersonallyIdentifiableInformation
member.summary: Indicates that the OP MUST not include any OpenID Attribute Exchange or Simple Registration information regarding the user in the assertion.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.AuthenticationPolicies.None
member.summary: Used in a PAPE response to indicate that no PAPE authentication policies could be satisfied.
member.remarks: Used internally by the PAPE extension, so that users don't have to know about it.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants
member.summary: OpenID Provider Authentication Policy extension constants.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.TypeUri
member.summary: The namespace used by this extension in messages.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.CompatibilityAlias
member.summary: The namespace alias to use for OpenID 1.x interop, where aliases are not defined in the message.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.AuthLevelNamespaceDeclarationPrefix
member.summary: The string to prepend on an Auth Level Type alias definition.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.AssuranceLevels
member.summary: Well-known assurance level Type URIs.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.AssuranceLevels.NistTypeUri
member.summary: The Type URI of the NIST assurance level.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.AssuranceLevels.PreferredTypeUriToAliasMap
member.summary: A mapping between the PAPE TypeURI and the alias to use if possible for backward compatibility reasons.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.RequestParameters
member.summary: Parameters to be included with PAPE requests.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.RequestParameters.MaxAuthAge
member.summary: Optional. If the End User has not actively authenticated to the OP within the number of seconds specified in a manner fitting the requested policies, the OP SHOULD authenticate the End User for this request.
member.value: Integer value greater than or equal to zero in seconds.
member.remarks: The OP should realize that not adhering to the request for re-authentication most likely means that the End User will not be allowed access to the services provided by the RP. If this parameter is absent in the request, the OP should authenticate the user at its own discretion.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.RequestParameters.PreferredAuthPolicies
member.summary: Zero or more authentication policy URIs that the OP SHOULD conform to when authenticating the user. If multiple policies are requested, the OP SHOULD satisfy as many as it can.
member.value: Space separated list of authentication policy URIs.
member.remarks: If no policies are requested, the RP may be interested in other information such as the authentication age.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.Constants.RequestParameters.PreferredAuthLevelTypes
member.summary: The space separated list of the name spaces of the custom Assurance Level that RP requests, in the order of its preference.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.DateTimeEncoder
member.summary: An encoder/decoder design for DateTimes that must conform to the PAPE spec.
member.remarks: The timestamp MUST be formatted as specified in section 5.6 of [RFC3339] (Klyne, G. and C. Newman, “Date and Time on the Internet: Timestamps,” .), with the following restrictions: * All times must be in the UTC timezone, indicated with a "Z". * No fractional seconds are allowed For example: 2005-05-15T17:11:51Z

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.DateTimeEncoder.PermissibleDateTimeFormats
member.summary: An array of the date/time formats allowed by the PAPE extension.
member.remarks: TODO: This array of formats is not yet a complete list.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.DateTimeEncoder.Encode(System.Object)
member.summary: Encodes the specified value.
member.param: The value. Guaranteed to never be null.
member.returns: The in string form, ready for message transport.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.DateTimeEncoder.Decode(System.String)
member.summary: Decodes the specified value.
member.param: The string value carried by the transport. Guaranteed to never be null, although it may be empty.
member.returns: The deserialized form of the given string.
member.exception: Thrown when the string value given cannot be decoded into the required object type.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.NistAssuranceLevel
member.summary: Descriptions for NIST-defined levels of assurance that a credential has not been compromised and therefore the extent to which an authentication assertion can be trusted.

remarks.para: One using this enum should review the following publication for details before asserting or interpreting what these levels signify, notwithstanding the brief summaries attached to each level in DotNetOpenAuth documentation. http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-63/SP800-63V1_0_2.pdf
See PAPE spec Appendix A.1.2 (NIST Assurance Levels) for high-level example classifications of authentication methods within the defined levels.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.NistAssuranceLevel.InsufficientForLevel1
member.summary: Not an assurance level defined by NIST, but rather SHOULD be used to signify that the OP recognizes the parameter and the End User authentication did not meet the requirements of Level 1.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.NistAssuranceLevel.Level1
member.summary: See this document for a thorough description: http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-63/SP800-63V1_0_2.pdf

member.summary: See this document for a thorough description: http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-63/SP800-63V1_0_2.pdf

member.summary: See this document for a thorough description: http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-63/SP800-63V1_0_2.pdf

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.PolicyRequest.MaximumAuthenticationAge
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum acceptable time since the End User has actively authenticated to the OP in a manner fitting the requested policies, beyond which the Provider SHOULD authenticate the End User for this request.
member.remarks: The OP should realize that not adhering to the request for re-authentication most likely means that the End User will not be allowed access to the services provided by the RP. If this parameter is absent in the request, the OP should authenticate the user at its own discretion.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.ProviderAuthenticationPolicy.PolicyRequest.PreferredPolicies
member.summary: Gets the list of authentication policy URIs that the OP SHOULD conform to when authenticating the user. If multiple policies are requested, the OP SHOULD satisfy as many as it can.
member.value: List of authentication policy URIs obtainable from the class or from a custom list.
member.remarks: If no policies are requested, the RP may be interested in other information such as the authentication age.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.UI.UIModes.Popup
member.summary: Indicates that the Provider's authentication page appears in a popup window.
member.value: The constant "popup".

remarks.para: The RP SHOULD create the popup to be 450 pixels wide and 500 pixels tall. The popup MUST have the address bar displayed, and MUST be in a standalone browser window. The contents of the popup MUST NOT be framed by the RP.

The RP SHOULD open the popup centered above the main browser window, and SHOULD dim the contents of the parent window while the popup is active. The RP SHOULD ensure that the user is not surprised by the appearance of the popup, and understands how to interact with it.

To keep the user popup user experience consistent, it is RECOMMENDED that the OP does not resize the popup window unless the OP requires additional space to show special features that are not usually displayed as part of the default popup user experience.
The OP MAY close the popup without returning a response to the RP. Closing the popup without sending a response should be interpreted as a negative assertion.

The response to an authentication request in a popup is unchanged from [OpenID 2.0] (OpenID 2.0 Workgroup, “OpenID 2.0,” .). Relying Parties detecting that the popup was closed without receiving an authentication response SHOULD interpret the close event to be a negative assertion.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.UI.UIRequest
member.summary: OpenID User Interface extension 1.0 request message.

remarks.para: Implements the extension described by: http://wiki.openid.net/f/openid_ui_extension_draft01.html
This extension only applies to checkid_setup requests, since checkid_immediate requests display no UI to the user.
For rules about how the popup window should be displayed, please see the documentation of .
An RP may determine whether an arbitrary OP supports this extension (and thereby determine whether to use a standard full window redirect or a popup) via the method.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.UI.UIRequest.GetRelyingPartyIconUrls(DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Realm,DotNetOpenAuth.Messaging.IDirectWebRequestHandler)
member.summary: Gets the URL of the RP icon for the OP to display.
member.param: The realm of the RP where the authentication request originated.
The web request handler to use for discovery. Usually available via OpenIdProvider.Channel.WebRequestHandler.
member.returns: A sequence of the RP's icons it has available for the Provider to display, in decreasing preferred order.
member.value: The icon URL.
member.remarks:
This property is automatically set for the OP with the result of RP discovery. RPs should set this value by including an entry such as this in their XRDS document.
<Service xmlns="xri://$xrd*($v*2.0)"> <Type>http://specs.openid.net/extensions/ui/icon</Type> <URI>http://consumer.example.com/images/image.jpg</URI> </Service>

member.remarks:
This property is automatically set for the OP with the result of RP discovery. RPs should set this value by including an entry such as this in their XRDS document.
<Service xmlns="xri://$xrd*($v*2.0)"> <Type>http://specs.openid.net/extensions/ui/icon</Type> <URI>http://consumer.example.com/images/image.jpg</URI> </Service>

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Extensions.UI.UIRequest.EnsureValidMessage
member.summary: Checks the message state for conformity to the protocol specification and throws an exception if the message is invalid.

remarks.para: Some messages have required fields, or combinations of fields that must relate to each other in specialized ways. After deserializing a message, this method checks the state of the message to see if it conforms to the protocol.
Note that this property should not check signatures or perform any state checks outside this scope of this particular message.

member.exception: Thrown if the message is invalid.

member.summary: Gets or sets the list of user's preferred languages, sorted in decreasing preferred order.
member.value: The default is the of the thread that created this instance.
member.remarks: The user's preferred languages as a [BCP 47] language priority list, represented as a comma-separated list of BCP 47 basic language ranges in descending priority order. For instance, the value "fr-CA,fr-FR,en-CA" represents the preference for French spoken in Canada, French spoken in France, followed by English spoken in Canada.

member.remarks: Useful for reading in messages with an older version of an extension. The value in the property is always checked before trying this list. If you do support multiple versions of an extension using this method, consider adding a CreateResponse method to your request extension class so that the response can have the context it needs to remain compatible given the version of the extension in the request message. member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The response.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Interop.AuthenticationResponseShim.ClaimedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets an Identifier that the end user claims to own. For use with user database storage and lookup. May be null for some failed authentications (i.e. failed directed identity authentications).

remarks.para: This is the secure identifier that should be used for database storage and lookup. It is not always friendly (i.e. =Arnott becomes =!9B72.7DD1.50A9.5CCD), but it protects user identities against spoofing and other attacks.
For user-friendly identifiers to display, use the property.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Interop.AuthenticationResponseShim.FriendlyIdentifierForDisplay
member.summary: Gets a user-friendly OpenID Identifier for display purposes ONLY.

remarks.para: This should be put through before sending to a browser to secure against javascript injection attacks.

This property retains some aspects of the user-supplied identifier that get lost in the . For example, XRIs used as user-supplied identifiers (i.e. =Arnott) become unfriendly unique strings (i.e. =!9B72.7DD1.50A9.5CCD). For display purposes, such as text on a web page that says "You're logged in as ...", this property serves to provide the =Arnott string, or whatever else is the most friendly string close to what the user originally typed in.

If the user-supplied identifier is a URI, this property will be the URI after all redirects, and with the protocol and fragment trimmed off. If the user-supplied identifier is an XRI, this property will be the original XRI. If the user-supplied identifier is an OpenID Provider identifier (i.e. yahoo.com), this property will be the Claimed Identifier, with the protocol stripped if it is a URI.
It is very important that this property never be used for database storage or lookup to avoid identity spoofing and other security risks. For database storage and lookup please use the property.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.CheckAuthenticationResponse.InvalidateHandle
member.summary: Gets or sets the handle the relying party should invalidate if is true.
member.value: The "invalidate_handle" value sent in the verification request, if the OP confirms it is invalid.

remarks.para: If present in a verification response with "is_valid" set to "true", the Relying Party SHOULD remove the corresponding association from its store and SHOULD NOT send further authentication requests with this handle.

This two-step process for invalidating associations is necessary to prevent an attacker from invalidating an association at will by adding "invalidate_handle" parameters to an authentication response.
For OpenID 1.1, we allow this to be present but empty to put up with poor implementations such as Blogger.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.SignedResponseRequest.AssociationHandle
member.summary: Gets or sets the handle of the association the RP would like the Provider to use for signing a positive assertion in the response message.
member.value: A handle for an association between the Relying Party and the OP that SHOULD be used to sign the response.
member.remarks: If no association handle is sent, the transaction will take place in Stateless Mode (Verifying Directly with the OpenID Provider).

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.SignedResponseRequest.ReturnTo
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL the Provider should redirect the user agent to following the authentication attempt.
member.value: URL to which the OP SHOULD return the User-Agent with the response indicating the status of the request.

remarks.para: If this value is not sent in the request it signifies that the Relying Party does not wish for the end user to be returned.

The return_to URL MAY be used as a mechanism for the Relying Party to attach context about the authentication request to the authentication response. This document does not define a mechanism by which the RP can ensure that query parameters are not modified by outside parties; such a mechanism can be defined by the RP itself.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.SignedResponseRequest.Realm
member.summary: Gets or sets the Relying Party discovery URL the Provider may use to verify the source of the authentication request.
member.value: URL pattern the OP SHOULD ask the end user to trust. See Section 9.2 (Realms). This value MUST be sent if openid.return_to is omitted. Default: The URL.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.SignedResponseRequest.SignReturnTo
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the return_to value should be signed.

member.exception: Thrown if the message is invalid.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.CheckIdRequest.ClaimedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the Claimed Identifier.

remarks.para: "openid.claimed_id" and "openid.identity" SHALL be either both present or both absent. If neither value is present, the assertion is not about an identifier, and will contain other information in its payload, using extensions (Extensions).
It is RECOMMENDED that OPs accept XRI identifiers with or without the "xri://" prefix, as specified in the Normalization (Normalization) section.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.CheckIdRequest.LocalIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the OP Local Identifier.
member.value: The OP-Local Identifier.

remarks.para: If a different OP-Local Identifier is not specified, the claimed identifier MUST be used as the value for openid.identity.

Note: If this is set to the special value "http://specs.openid.net/auth/2.0/identifier_select" then the OP SHOULD choose an Identifier that belongs to the end user. This parameter MAY be omitted if the request is not about an identifier (for instance if an extension is in use that makes the request meaningful without it; see openid.claimed_id above).

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.AssociateSuccessfulResponse
member.summary: The base class that all successful association response messages derive from.
member.remarks: Association response messages are described in OpenID 2.0 section 8.2. This type covers section 8.2.1.

remarks.para: The response message is updated to include the details of the created association by this method, but the resulting association is not added to the association store and must be done by the caller.

member.summary: Gets or sets the signed parameter order.

Additional keys MAY be signed as part of the message. See Generating Signatures.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Messages.IndirectSignedResponse.ResponseNonceTestHook
member.summary: Gets or sets the nonce that will protect the message from replay attacks.

value.para: A string 255 characters or less in length, that MUST be unique to this particular successful authentication response. The nonce MUST start with the current time on the server, and MAY contain additional ASCII characters in the range 33-126 inclusive (printable non-whitespace characters), as necessary to make each response unique. The date and time MUST be formatted as specified in section 5.6 of [RFC3339] (Klyne, G. and C. Newman, “Date and Time on the Internet: Timestamps,” .), with the following restrictions:

list.item: All times must be in the UTC timezone, indicated with a "Z".

member.summary: Changes the position of some element in a list.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.OpenIdUtilities.FixDoublyUriDecodedBase64String(System.String)
member.summary: Corrects any URI decoding the Provider may have inappropriately done to our return_to URL, resulting in an otherwise corrupted base64 encoded value.
member.param: The base64 encoded value. May be null.
member.returns: The value; corrected if corruption had occurred.
member.remarks: AOL may have incorrectly URI-decoded the token for us in the return_to, resulting in a token URI-decoded twice by the time we see it, and no longer being a valid base64 string. It turns out that the only symbols from base64 that is also encoded in URI encoding rules are the + and / characters. AOL decodes the %2b sequence to the + character and the %2f sequence to the / character (it shouldn't decode at all). When we do our own URI decoding, the + character becomes a space (corrupting base64) but the / character remains a /, so no further corruption happens to this character. So to correct this we just need to change any spaces we find in the token back to + characters.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.OpenIdUtilities.CutToSecond(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Rounds the given downward to the whole second.
member.param: The DateTime object to adjust.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.PrivatePersonalIdentifierProviderBase
member.summary: Provides standard PPID Identifiers to users to protect their identity from individual relying parties and from colluding groups of relying parties.

member.name: T:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IDirectedIdentityIdentifierProvider
member.summary: An interface to provide custom identifiers for users logging into specific relying parties.
member.remarks: This interface would allow, for example, the Provider to offer PPIDs to their users, allowing the users to log into RPs without leaving any clue as to their true identity, and preventing multiple RPs from colluding to track user activity across realms.

member.summary: A granularity description for who wide of an audience sees the same generated PPID.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.PrivatePersonalIdentifierProviderBase.AudienceScope.Realm
member.summary: A unique Identifier is generated for every realm. This is the highest security setting.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.PrivatePersonalIdentifierProviderBase.AudienceScope.RealmHost
member.summary: Only the host name in the realm is used in calculating the PPID, allowing for some level of sharing of the PPID Identifiers between RPs that are able to share the same realm host value.

member.name: F:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.PrivatePersonalIdentifierProviderBase.AudienceScope.Global
member.summary: Although the user's Identifier is still opaque to the RP so they cannot determine who the user is at the OP, the same Identifier is used at all RPs so collusion between the RPs is possible.

member.summary: Instances of this interface represent incoming authentication requests. This interface provides the details of the request and allows setting the response.

member.name: M:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.SetClaimedIdentifierFragment(System.String)
member.summary: Adds an optional fragment (#fragment) portion to the ClaimedIdentifier. Useful for identifier recycling.
member.param: Should not include the # prefix character as that will be added internally. May be null or the empty string to clear a previously set fragment.

remarks.para: Unlike the property, which can only be set if using directed identity, this method can be called on any URI claimed identifier.
Because XRI claimed identifiers (the canonical IDs) are never recycled, this method shouldnot be called for XRIs.

member.exception: Thrown when this method is called on an XRI, or on a directed identity request before the property is set.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.IsDirectedIdentity
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Provider should help the user select a Claimed Identifier to send back to the relying party.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.IsDelegatedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the requesting Relying Party is using a delegated URL.
member.remarks: When delegated identifiers are used, the should not be changed at the Provider during authentication. Delegation is only detectable on requests originating from OpenID 2.0 relying parties. A relying party implementing only OpenID 1.x may use delegation and this property will return false anyway.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.LocalIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the Local Identifier to this OpenID Provider of the user attempting to authenticate. Check to see if this value is valid.
member.remarks: This may or may not be the same as the Claimed Identifier that the user agent originally supplied to the relying party. The Claimed Identifier endpoint may be delegating authentication to this provider using this provider's local id, which is what this property contains. Use this identifier when looking up this user in the provider's user account list.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.ClaimedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the identifier that the user agent is claiming at the relying party site. Check to see if this value is valid.

remarks.para: This property can only be set if is false, to prevent breaking URL delegation.
This will not be the same as this provider's local identifier for the user if the user has set up his/her own identity page that points to this provider for authentication.
The provider may use this identifier for displaying to the user when asking for the user's permission to authenticate to the relying party.

member.exception: Thrown from the setter if is true.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequest.IsAuthenticated
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the provider has determined that the belongs to the currently logged in user and wishes to share this information with the consumer.

Because XRI claimed identifiers (the canonical IDs) are never recycled, this method shouldnot be called for XRIs.

member.exception: Thrown when this method is called on an XRI, or on a directed identity request before the property is set.

member.param: The OpenIdProvider that is performing the RP discovery.

remarks.para: Return URL verification is only attempted if this method is called.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Provider should help the user select a Claimed Identifier to send back to the relying party.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequestContract.DotNetOpenAuth#OpenId#Provider#IAuthenticationRequest#IsDelegatedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the requesting Relying Party is using a delegated URL.
member.remarks: When delegated identifiers are used, the should not be changed at the Provider during authentication. Delegation is only detectable on requests originating from OpenID 2.0 relying parties. A relying party implementing only OpenID 1.x may use delegation and this property will return false anyway.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequestContract.DotNetOpenAuth#OpenId#Provider#IAuthenticationRequest#LocalIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the Local Identifier to this OpenID Provider of the user attempting to authenticate. Check to see if this value is valid.
member.remarks: This may or may not be the same as the Claimed Identifier that the user agent originally supplied to the relying party. The Claimed Identifier endpoint may be delegating authentication to this provider using this provider's local id, which is what this property contains. Use this identifier when looking up this user in the provider's user account list.

member.name: P:DotNetOpenAuth.OpenId.Provider.IAuthenticationRequestContract.DotNetOpenAuth#OpenId#Provider#IAuthenticationRequest#ClaimedIdentifier
member.summary: Gets or sets the identifier that the user agent is claiming at the relying party site. Check to see if this value is valid.

remarks.para: This property can only be set if is false, to prevent breaking URL delegation.
This will not be the same as this provider's local identifier for the user if the user has set up his/her own identity page that points to this provider for authentication.
The provider may use this identifier for displaying to the user when asking for the user's permission to authenticate to the relying party.

member.exception: Thrown from the setter if is true.
